qas.question: Who was an exponent of so-called "Boston Personalism"?
What was the term given to the personal idealism of Howison?
Who is a notable realistic personal theist?
What issue do both Aquinas and Brightman discuss?

answers.text: dependence upon an infinite personal God

qas.question: What sort of freedom did Howison believe was incompatible with materialism?
California Personalism is the same as what personalism by Bowne?

plausible_answers.text: Borden Parker Bowne and Edgar S. Brightman

qas.question: What two idealists took a realistic perspective?
What theist did Howison agree with?
What did Bowne believe was contrary to moral freedom?
Howison said materialism was compatible with moral what?

context: Howison's personal idealism  was also called "<a1_0>California Personalism<a1_0/>" by others to distinguish it from the "<b5_0>Boston Personalism<b5_0/>" which was of <a0_0>Bowne<a0_0/>. Howison maintained that both <b8_0>impersonal, monistic idealism and materialism<b8_0/> run contrary to the experience of <a4_0>moral<a4_0/> <b9_0>freedom<b9_0/>. To deny freedom to pursue truth, beauty, and "benignant love" is to undermine every profound human venture, including science, morality, and philosophy. Personalistic idealists <b6_0>Borden Parker Bowne and Edgar S. Brightman<b6_0/> and realistic personal theist <a2_0><b7_0>Saint Thomas Aquinas<b7_0/><a2_0/> address a core issue, namely that of <a3_0>dependence upon an infinite personal God<a3_0/>.
